entry.title: Universal Revenue Recognition (URR) Configuration Walkthrough – Release 2602
entry.content:
Introduction

This guide walks you through the configuration of Universal Revenue Recognition (URR). URR combines Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) and Contract-Based Revenue Recognition (CBRR) and therefore consists of two main parts: configuration in EBRR and configuration in CBRR. Because URR leverages the strengths of both approaches, the EBRR and CBRR settings apply to different areas.

 

Configuration in EBRR relates to:

  – Integration with business processes

  – Account determination

  – Posting rules

Configuration in CBRR relates to:

  – Deriving attributes for CBRR-related  objects

  – Defining standalone selling price (SSP) for price allocation when an SSP cannot be defined in the order system

General steps

Below are the configuration steps at a glance:

Pricing configuration in Sales

  1. Define a condition type for SSP
  2.  Add the SSP condition type to the pricing procedure
  3.  Maintain SSP condition records for the product

Configuration in EBRR:

  1.  Maintain Source Mapping (optional)
  2.  Maintain Accounts for Posting (optional)
  3.  Define Billable Determination Method (required)
  4.  Enable 'Use Revenue Contracts' via the Bundling Scenario

Configuration in CBRR (Revenue and Cost Accounting)

  1.   Maintain contract and POB attributes
  2.   Define Standalone Selling Price (optional — only if SSP is not defined in Sales)

This guide focuses on the configuration in EBRR and CBRR. Pricing configuration in Sales for SSP is covered in a separate blog, as it depends on the specific business process.

Prerequisites

  • Activate the relevant scope items for Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) and Contract-Based Revenue Recognition (CBRR).
  • For EBRR, there are separate scope items for each integration scenario, such as 1K2 (Event Based Revenue Recognition - Sell from Stock) or 3M4 Event-Based Revenue Recognition – Service Documents – IFRS (3M4)

Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) Setup

Start in the Profitability Analysis area under Revenue Recognition. This is the starting point because EBRR defines the integration scenarios.

Maintain Source for the condition (Optional)

If revenue contracts are used, each pricing condition type must be mapped to a source. The system checks this mapping during revenue contract creation. This step is optional if you do not change SAP’s default configuration, which already contains predefined mappings.

As you can see, SAP has predefined the mapping of the condition types to the sources.  If you introduce a new condition type or add a condition type to a pricing procedure, ensure you map it to a source in the EBRR configuration.

Example: if you add condition type DSV1 to the pricing scheme in Subscription Billing and DSV1 is not mapped, add DSV1 to source RPC and create custom rules (e.g., rule numbers starting from 1000).

This ensures the condition type is recognized during processing; otherwise, revenue contract creation will fail due to missing source mapping.

Maintain Accounts for the Posting (Optional)

Now we are in the second step, and this step is optional but usually every customer defines its own account.

 

The account determination during posting is defined in event-based revenue recognition. In most cases, you need to define the following accounts

  • Deferrals Account: you define the deferrals account of usage 100
  • Accrued/Contract Asset Account: you define the accruals account of usage 100
  • Revenue Account: Cost Element Accounts of usage 100
  • Unbilled Account: you define the accruals account of usage 103 and the cost element account shall be the same as the one in usage 100.

Maintain Billable Determination Method (required)

Per IFRS 15/ASC 606, you must define what is billable to distinguish billable amounts from contract assets. When 'Use Revenue Contracts' is set, the system validates that the revenue recognition key has a billable determination method.  In ‘Maintain settings’ for the Revenue Recognition Key, you define how billable is calculated.

Supported method:

  • Billable equals Invoice:
  • Billable follows Percentage of Completion: 
  • Billable at completion:

At least one billable determination method must be maintained for the key used in processing. Otherwise,  you may get an error at configuration to enable ‘Use Revenue Recontracts’ or later at period end run.

Use the new ‘Bundling Scenario’ Field to Enable ‘Use Revenue Contracts’

In this step, we define when a product of a process shall create revenue contract and how different products from different process shall be combined into single revenue contracts.

  • Open ‘Define Revenue Recognition Key’ for the relevant Process (e.g., Provider Contract for Subscription Billing).
  • Bundling Scenario is determined by whether an object is created standalone or from a Solution Order.
    • Per Standard Objects: When the object is created directly (without Solution Order).
    • Per Solution Order: When the object is created from a Solution Order

  • When Bundling Scenario is set to Per Solution Order, ‘Use Revenue Contract’ becomes active for the key.
  • With this, all objects created from a same Solution Order are combined into one revenue contract.
  • This behavior can be applied across different business processes (service contract, provider contract, project, sales order). For example, in one solution order there are service contracts and sales orders, and the revenue recognition key of the service contracts and sales orders are defined as ‘Use Revenue Contract’, the  one revenue contract will be created with POBs from each service contract and sales orders.

Advanced — Using revenue contracts for standalone objects

  • Using revenue contracts for standalone objects (when bundle scenario is per standalone Objects not created from Solution Order) is supported only via expert configuration.
  • Please raise a request to SAP; SAP reviews the business process and enables the setup if appropriate.

 

Contract-Based Revenue Recognition (CBRR) Setup

Maintain Contract Attributes using Business Rule Framework (BRF+) rules

Now we start the configuraiton in CBRR.

  • To enable revenue contract creation, maintain the BRF+ rules required by revenue contracts.
  • You  "Maintain Contract Attributes Business Rules"

Note: The system requires you at least trigger the configuration so that the businss rule is created and put into a transport request. 
You must also allow the pop-up option of your browser!!!

Since 2602, a well-defined pre-delivered configuration is available as part of the application, usually you would not need to change the pre-delivered rules from SAP.  The product ID is taken as the POB Name, and the fulill type and event type are preconfigured according to the reveneu recognition key.

 

Define Standalone Selling Price(Optional)

If the product cannot have a standalone selling price defined in the pricing procedure in solution order), you can still define the SSP using the rule ‘in CBRR. 

You can define the SSP per product and define how the SSP is calculated such as the amount is quarterly based, monthly

 

 

Up to now, the configuration is completed, and you can now run the End-2-End scenario starting from Solution Order to Financial Accounting.

Hello Ronald,

Yes, the Group Logistics Company Process is support only in Side Car TM, as mentioned in the Oss Note 3615236 - SAP S/4HANA 2025 Supply Chain for Transportation Management - Release information - SAP for Me

Having the Central Procurare company in TM you will need to follow the MM Organization Structure in TM so you can create your PO/SES/Invoice without problem for the Cross Integration.

By other hand you will need to enable the Cost distribution to have the ABD document and be able to have the cost of the transport in the material Valuation or CO-PA for the receiving Plant of this Transports.

As the  Group Logistics is not available in TM embedded you, I see as alternative use the value of the ABD document to have the internal cost recharge on FI side, to have the Intercompany cost process.

Regards,

Rogerio

entry.title: Security change with ByD release 2602
entry.content:
As par of security best practices, we are disabling the previewing the attachments in browser or new tab, across ByD.

Same for documents which are opened via the document name and output History

This is significant change of behavior with respective to viewing attachments, customer must download to their local desktop to view the attachment.

 

In 2602 release affects the following areas:

  • Customer Invoicing
  • Sales Orders
  • Supplier Invoices (invoices and credit memos)
  • Payables, Liquidity Management (including Bank Statements)
  • File Management

 

In subsequent releases we disable previewing attachments in remaining places.

 

Benefits:

  • Improved Security : Download only access ensures that sensitive documents are not rendered inside the browser, reducing exposure to browser based vulnerabilities and aligning better with corporate security policies.
  • Reduced Rendering Issues: Some attachments may not display correctly in the browser due to format limitations or browser compatibility issues. Downloading ensures documents are opened in their native application, preserving full quality and formatting.

entry.title: Re: The consequences of implementing strictly Shift-left architectures
entry.content:
Hi Phil I hope Madrid is not very cold.

You did a fantastic breakdown of the "Shift Left" into SAP, I liked it; you’ve really captured a model where data is born as a product.

From my perspective, focusing on SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and its integration with Databricks or similar, makes us rethink the Medallion Architecture. Still, it is more important to note the role shift required.

The traditional "Bronze" layer (raw dump) becomes less relevant. With SAP BDC, we need a Silver layer effectively moving into the backend or the BDC FOS. The data exposed via CDS views or as Martin says the Data Product Generator, is already semantically rich and governed, if all this works, it removes the need for that initial "landing zone" cleanup we used to do in BW or early Data Lakes.

What you mentioned, "Analytical Extensions" (like Churn Risk or CLV) as sidecar products might be done with  SAP + Databricks and the core "Silver" data product (e.g., Global Material) remains owned by the SAP backend (the "Semantic remains in SAP"), the "Gold" layer sits in Databricks for high-end ML/AI workloads.

The biggest hurdle is the skill gap.  As you noted, backend developers (often ABAP-focused) are now expected to be "Data Product Owners," and that is not in their hands; it's a complete customer restructure.

Data Products is treating the data as a product, meaning there is an owner who is going to continuously curate it. SAP tools are still incomplete for this end-to-end task. BDC is still in the making, so are many customers in this paradigm right now.

Still,  many legacy landscapes ("Brownfield"), and we are yet to see the Data Product Builder and how BDC integrates with non SAP data as BW could do.

I will wait for your next blog.

entry.title: Clean core journey - Guidance, implementation & governance
entry.content:
This blog post aims to give a high-level overview of your clean core journey as part of our S/4HANA Cloud private edition greenfield implementation! It focuses on clean core tracking and governance!

Step 1 

Our clean core journey started with creating an extensibility strategy. This includes raising awareness for the topic and why it is important, as well as creating a common understanding

Step 2

Create your development guidelines based on the extensibility strategy.

Step 3

Review and approve technical specifications.

Step 4

For governance reasons, we created a clean core ATC check variant. We use this check variant in multiple ways:

  1. when releasing TRs
  2. custom code migration app
  3. integrated into our Cloud ALM change & deployment process

We created a second ATC check variant for the exports to Cloud ALM (system view and customer objects).

Step 5

A simple and early way of tracking was using tagging in Cloud ALM - create a tag group and tag your requirements/user stories, specs (documents), and features accordingly! Once available, we started exploring the RISE with SAP Methodology space and its apps in Cloud ALM!

Using its KPIs, the system view app provides a nice overview of the clean core status quo regarding extensibility.

To be honest, I was surprised by the number of Level D objects (especially when seen in relation to the number of Level B objects). So I was looking forward to being able to see which objects are shown as Level D.

Since last Wednesday's delivery, you can dive one lever deeper, by having a look on object level. So, of course, I had to try out the new customer objects app immediately. 

The result list contains the following object types:

  • Enhancement Implementation (#72)
  • Function Group (#3)
  • Program (#19)
  • Class (ABAP Objects) (#3)

All Function groups and a couple of enhancement implementations are from third-party addons.

To cross-check my understanding of the "new" level concept, I had a look at the classification in two different SAP whitepapers:

Source: Clean core extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud



Source: Extend SAP S/4HANA in the cloud and on premise with ABAP based extensions

In my opinion, the second overview with the examples is quite helpful, as it, for example, also shows that BAdIs that are flagged as SAP internal are also considered as level D. On the other hand, it classifies "custom applications with legacy UI technology (e.g. ABAP report with ALV)" as level B, so I need to check why some of the programs that fall in this category are shown as Level D in the customer objects app.


Side remark: Personally, I am not a big fan of the new level concept. I understand that the old tier concept was difficult for customers who migrated from their ECC systems to S/4HANA. However, if you do a greenfield implementation based on best practices with a Fiori first approach, the old tier concept was the better fit (imho). In such a scenario,  you still don't want to use the old GUI ALV but would instead aim for e.g. a Fiori Elements application - just to give one example!

Coming back to the new customer objects app...in the upcoming weeks, I want to have a closer look at all objects and get a better understanding of the information that is shown on the detail page! Next to the upcoming executive dashboard, another great step forward would be to integrate the new customer objects app with the library app. Being able to import the data from the customer objects app into the library app and navigating to the corresponding library entry would be awesome. Once the library elements are finally linked to requirements, features, and user stories (currently on the roadmap for Q3/2026) that would be next level!

What are your thoughts on the new level concept? Where are you in your clean core journey? How do you track your clean core journey? Happy to get your feedback in the comments!

PS: For those who are new to the topic, I can recommend the learning journeys Practicing Clean Core Extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud & Introducing the Clean Core Approach (from an Integration perspective).

entry.title: Re: MCP Server for On Premise data
entry.content:
Hi Sumant, 

That plan to wrap OData services via an MCP server on BTP is good, but converting everything to ODP/OData means you need to first expose the ECC data as OData services, maintain those services, and then wrap them again via MCP. That's two abstraction layers when you could potentially have one.

We are limited to what OData exposes from ECC or S/4HANA. What about function modules, BAPIs, or custom ABAP logic that isn't (and shouldn't be) exposed as OData?

If we had a pure ABAP MCP server, many things would be solved. Access to tables, FMs, BAPIs, and CDS views that are not odata translated. No Python runtime on BTP, no dependency on FastMCP, just ABAP running where the data already lives.

I know there are already some people on that, and the challenge apparently is implementing the SSE (Server-Sent Events) transport that MCP uses for streaming, which requires an ABAP workaround.

That would be cool also.

entry.title: 🎯 Lite Plan Deprecation: Time to Upgrade to Free! 🚀 | SAP Job Scheduling service
entry.content:
🎯 Lite Plan Deprecation: Time to Upgrade to Free! 🚀

Great news! The SAP Job Scheduling Service is evolving to provide you with better capabilities and a more consistent experience across Trial and Production environments. As part of this evolution, we're saying goodbye to the Lite plan and inviting everyone to upgrade to the superior Free plan! 🎉

 

📅 Important Timeline

Here's what you need to know:

DateEventStatus

22 January 2026Lite plan officially deprecated on SAP BTP Trial⚠️ Announced
19 February 2026Last day to create new Lite plan instances🔒 No new instances
Going forwardExisting Lite instances will be removed♻️ Migrate to Free

ℹ️ Note: SAP BTP Trial accounts typically live for 90 days. Your existing Lite instances will be removed as part of the natural trial lifecycle.

If you want to stay up-to-date with the latest announcements, check out the SAP Job Scheduling Service What's New page.

🌟 Why This Change is Good News

The Lite plan served us well, but it was time for an upgrade! Here's why the Free plan is a much better choice:

Lite Plan Limitations 😕

  • 🔐 Basic authentication only (outdated security model)
  • 🔄 Works differently than production Standard plan (confusing!)
  • 📚 Limited REST API capabilities
  • 🏢 No multitenancy support
  • 🎓 Steeper learning curve when moving to production

Free Plan Advantages 🎊

  • 🔒 OAuth 2.0 authentication - Modern, secure, production-ready
  • 🎯 Works like Standard plan - Smooth transition to production
  • 🚀 Full REST API support - All features unlocked
  • 🏢 Multitenancy ready - Build tenant-aware solutions
  • ✨ Better integration - Works seamlessly with other BTP services
  • 📊 More capabilities - Alert Notification Service, Cloud Foundry tasks, and more!

📊 Plan Comparison: Lite vs. Free vs. Standard

Here's a detailed comparison to help you understand the differences:

FeatureLite (Deprecated)Free ⭐Standard

AvailabilityTrial only 🧪Trial only 🧪 (for now)Trial & Production 🌍
AuthenticationBasic Auth 🔓OAuth 2.0 🔒OAuth 2.0 🔒
Security ModelUsername/PasswordJWT tokensJWT tokens
Number of SchedulesLimited 15 ⚠️Limited 15 ⚠️Unlimited ♾️
Minimal Interval1 hour ⏰1 hour ⏰5 minutes ⚡
Multitenancy❌✅✅
Alert Notification Service❌✅✅
Cloud ALM Monitoring❌✅✅
Alignment with StandardDifferent behavior✅-
SupportCommunity 👥Community 👥SLA-backed 🛡️
Production ReadyLearningLearning/Prototyping✅ Yes

💡 Key Takeaway: Free plan gives you almost the same capabilities as Standard plan, just with thoughtful limitations perfect for learning and prototyping. When you're ready for production, the transition is seamless!

🎁 What You Get with the Free Plan

Let's celebrate what the Free plan brings to the table:

⏰ Hourly Scheduling

Schedule jobs every hour - perfect for periodic reports, cleanup tasks, and regular data processing.

📊 15 Schedules

More than enough for learning, testing, and small applications. Build real-world solutions without hitting limits!

🔔 Unlimited Alert Notifications

Integrate with SAP Alert Notification Service to get notified when jobs succeed or fail.

🔒 Production-Like Security

Learn OAuth 2.0 authentication in Trial, so you're ready for production. No re-learning required!

🏢 Multitenancy Support

Build and test tenant-aware applications right in your Trial account.

🚀 Full Feature Set

Access to Cloud Foundry tasks, async jobs, REST API - everything you need to build sophisticated scheduling solutions!

🎯 Who Should Use the Free Plan?

The Free plan is perfect for:

  • 🎓 Students & Learners - Explore Job Scheduling without costs
  • 🧪 Developers - Prototype and test scheduling logic
  • 🎨 Proof of Concepts - Build demos and validate ideas
  • 📚 Tutorial Followers - Work through our blog posts and documentation
  • 🚀 Indie Developers - Power personal projects and experiments
  • 🏢 Enterprises - Evaluate features before production deployment

🚀 Getting Started with Free Plan

Ready to make the switch? It's easy!

1️⃣ Create a Free Plan Instance

Using the SAP BTP Cockpit:

  1. Navigate to your Trial subaccount
  2. Go to Service Marketplace
  3. Find SAP Job Scheduling Service
  4. Click Create
  5. Select service plan: free
  6. Follow the wizard to complete creation

Using the Cloud Foundry CLI:

cf create-service jobscheduler free my-scheduler-free

2️⃣ Bind to Your Application

In your manifest.yml:

applications:
  - name: my-app
    services:
      - my-scheduler-free

Or create a service key for REST API access:

cf create-service-key my-scheduler-free my-key
cf service-key my-scheduler-free my-key

3️⃣ Start Scheduling!

Access the dashboard or use the REST API to create your first scheduled job!

🎊 Embrace the Upgrade!

This change is all about giving you a better experience. The Free plan:

  • ✅ Teaches you production patterns - No surprises when you go live
  • ✅ Unlocks more features - Do more with your Trial account
  • ✅ Simplifies your journey - One security model to learn
  • ✅ Future-proofs your code - OAuth 2.0 is the standard

We're excited for you to experience the improved capabilities of the Free plan! 🚀

📝 Appendix: Migration Guide (Optional)

If you currently have applications using the Lite plan and want to migrate to the Free plan, here's what you need to know:

Key Differences to Handle

🔐 Authentication Change: Basic Auth → OAuth 2.0

Lite Plan (Basic Auth):

// Simple HTTP basic authentication
const credentials = Buffer.from(`${username}:${password}`).toString('base64');
const response = await fetch(jobUrl, {
  headers: {
    'Authorization': `Basic ${credentials}`
  }
});

Free Plan (OAuth 2.0):

// OAuth 2.0 with JWT tokens
const xsenv = require('@sap/xsenv');
const passport = require('passport');
const { JWTStrategy } = require('@sap/xssec');

// Configure authentication
passport.use(new JWTStrategy(xsenv.getServices({ uaa: { tag: 'xsuaa' } }).uaa));

app.use(passport.initialize());
app.use(passport.authenticate('JWT', { session: false }));

📦 Service Binding Changes

Lite Plan:

  • No XSUAA service binding required
  • Simple username/password from service key

Free Plan:

  • Requires XSUAA service instance and binding
  • Uses JWT tokens for authentication
  • Service-to-service communication with OAuth 2.0

🔧 Migration Steps

  1. Create Free plan instance

    cf create-service jobscheduler free my-scheduler-free

  2. Create or update XSUAA service instance

    Create xs-security.json:

    {
  "xsappname": "my-app",
  "scopes": [
    {
      "name": "$XSAPPNAME.Jobs",
      "description": "SAP Job Scheduling service Scope",
      "grant-as-authority-to-apps": [
        "$XSSERVICENAME(my-scheduler-free)"
      ]
    }
  ]
}

    📖 Learn more: Secure Access to Job Scheduling Service

    Create XSUAA instance:

    cf create-service xsuaa application my-xsuaa -c xs-security.json

  3. Update your application

    Add dependencies to package.json:

    {
  "dependencies": {
    "@sap/xsenv": "^5.3.0",
    "@sap/xssec": "^4.2.5",
    "passport": "^0.7.0",
    "express": "^4.21.2"
  }
}

  4. Update manifest.yml

    applications:
  - name: my-app
    services:
      - my-scheduler-free
      - my-xsuaa

  5. Redeploy your application

    cf push

💡 Need Help?

You can just drop a comment to start a discussion or look through the following resources:

  • 📖 Job Scheduling Service Documentation
  • 🌐 SAP Community
  • 📚 All Job Scheduler Blog Posts

Happy Scheduling with your new Free plan! 🎉🚀

The SAP Job Scheduling Service Team

Net Production Time of individual parent resource is calculated using the formula Total Production Time - Shift Break - Unscheduled Downtime - Scheduled Downtime, see Work Center Performance Calculation for more details.

For completed orders generating speed loss, I suggest you raise a ticket for proper investigation and support.

entry.title: Re: How to Disable Message Panel in Create Purchase Order (Advanced)
entry.content:
Dear @Keratiya_D,

What you are seeing is the in-app help / information side panel of Create Purchase Order  Advanced (ME21N/WebGUI). Closing the panel alone does not persist the setting, it is only persisted when the user saves Personal Settings in that app.

How to stop it showing by default (per user):

  • Open Create Purchase Order Advanced
  • Close the left information/help panel
  • Open Personal Settings in the same app
  • Click Save (you do not need to change anything)
  • Close and reopen the app the panel should no longer open automatically for you

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2971411

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: LOSC not working after deconsolidation when putaway HU contains items from different IBD deliveries
entry.content:
Hello,

I am trying to configure inbound process combining POSC (unload, deconsolidation, putaway) + LOSC (id-point for the destination storage types)  in order to receive and sort materials that will be stored on a 3 level mezzanine with small parts shelves.

i want to receive multiple deliveries and sort them at deconsolidation WC - where i would have 3 HU's, one by consolidation group - mixing all deliveries in those 3 HU's to their max capacity; and only then staring the final putaway step, flowing via the id-points.

scenario working fine:

if i deconsolidate a single HU (from a single inbound) which contains 2 materials - each one going to different mezzanine levels - LOSC is triggered and, after HU completion at WC, 2 HU WT are created to move them (WPT 3030) to the id-points of each mezzanine level and a stacker is called to move those HU's; after completion, final putaway Product WT's are created.

scenario not working (simple example):

we have to identical inbound deliveries (IBD#1 with HU#1 and IBD#2 with HU#2) - same 2 materials mentioned above - and we deconsolidate both to the same HUs:

hu.consolidation.group#1 now contains 2EA of material#1, one from IBD#1 HU#1, the other from IBD#2 HU#2

hu.consolidation.group#2 now contains 2EA of material#2, one from IBD#1 HU#1, the other from IBD#2 HU#2

so, in this scenario, at HU completion at WC, no movement to the id-point is created and instead only Product WT for final destination are created; LOSC is lost.

I tend to think this must be an available scenario; I've searched the community, some with similar doubts, but no clear answer.

So, has anyone come across this issue and managed to solve it? If so, via configuration (what is the tweak?) or with some BADI?

Thank you,

Best regards

entry.title: Re: The consequences of implementing strictly Shift-left architectures
entry.content:
I need to comment on what the current version of datasphere, data products and Databricks really gives. It is not as "semantically rich and governed" as you may believe.

a) When you extract data from a CDS view the associated data are not coming through to Datasphere. Instead you rebuild them in Datasphere by extracting master data and text and then creating master data views that you then associated to your fact view. In you analytical model you choose which parts of the associated data you want to expose to the user.

b) Only data physically stored in the object store can be shared with databricks using data products. I.e. you copy your data to the object store. If you "copy" from the views created in a) you don't get your associated data in, i.e. no text on technical columns and no additional master data (i.e. not semantically rich). You will have to either build another view where you join master data and text to the view or you will have to create data product where you deliver these side tables as separate tables in the data product, including a how-to join things together description.

The idea of governed and semantically rich data is fine, but there is quite a long way before we are there. Not that I really mind as it could be hard to handle and understand a data set with fully exploded master data into the transactional data, it would be hundreds of columns without a clear link between source and column (e.g. is the procuct hiearchy coming from the transaction the product or the product compounded to sales organisation?). 

-Kristian

entry.title: Master Cloud Foundry Management in the SAP BTP Cockpit with Our New Tutorial Series
entry.content:
What You'll Learn

The Learn How to Manage Your Cloud Foundry Environment in the SAP BTP Cockpit series of 13 tutorials helps you master key tasks for managing your Cloud Foundry environment in the SAP BTP cockpit. These tutorials cover user management, application deployment, and monitoring, among other topics:

1. Getting Started with Cloud Foundry Environment and SAP BTP Cockpit
2. Understanding Spaces
3. Understanding Space Quotas
4. Managing Org Members
5. Managing Space Members
6. Deploying Applications
7. Managing Deployed Applications
8. Monitoring Applications and Spaces with Events and Logs
9. Managing Routes
10. Understanding Service Bindings
11. Understanding Environment Variables
12. Managing User-Provided Environment Variables
13. Understanding Security Groups

 

Getting Started

While the tutorials are designed to work best when completed in order, each one is also standalone. This means you can jump directly to topics that interest you most or address your immediate needs.

To help you practice, we've included two sample applications - one built with Node.js and another with Java. Download them from our GitHub repository, or feel free to use your own applications.

 

Need Help?

Running into any challenges? Don't hesitate to reach out. Drop your questions in the comments below, and we'll be happy to help.

Whether you're new to Cloud Foundry or looking to sharpen your skills, these tutorials will help you navigate the SAP BTP cockpit with confidence.

entry.title: 5th SIBS Partners Meeting: Innovation with connectivity: SIBS with SAP
entry.content:
Last Thursday, I had the pleasure of participating,  in the 5th SIBS Partners Meeting, held at Quinta da Atela, in Alpiarça. Once again, the event proved to be a key moment for knowledge sharing, strategic alignment, and strengthening the partner ecosystem around SIBS and its technologies.

This fifth edition reinforced the focus on collaboration, technological innovation and future vision, while also bringing new and highly relevant topics to the forefront — particularly the real impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) on partner products, business models and go-to-market strategies.

Two panels, one shared goal: creating value

The event featured two discussion panels, both offering strong practical and strategic insights.

The first panel focused on the relationship between SIBS and its partners, addressing:

  • Different interaction models with SIBS

  • Real examples of products and solutions built on SIBS technologies

  • Technical, operational and integration challenges in real market contexts

This discussion clearly highlighted the maturity of the partner ecosystem and the importance of a collaborative approach to accelerate innovation while ensuring secure, scalable and reliable solutions.

The second panel was dedicated to Artificial Intelligence in partner products, fostering an open and pragmatic discussion around:

  • Security challenges related to the adoption of AI

  • The impact of AI on product value propositions

  • Commercial challenges and opportunities, including how AI can drive differentiation, sales growth and new business models

It became evident that AI is no longer just a technological topic, but a strategic business driver, requiring the right balance between innovation, trust, compliance and commercial viability.

Recognition for  SAP–SIBS interface award

For me, one of the most significant moments of the event was the recognition given to Makevalue, which I represented, that received an award for the SAP–SIBS interface developed throughout 2025. I participated in this project in 2025, and it was a game-changer in terms of knowledge sharing and a comprehensive approach to product development: purpose, security, technology, sales, and marketing.

This project was a key enabler for the official certification of SAP/SIBS connectivity by SIBS, representing an important milestone in the integration between SAP systems and the SIBS payments and services ecosystem.

The solution was developed within the scope of a SIBS LABS project, further underlining its innovative nature and the strong collaboration between the technical and functional teams involved.

This recognition reinforces Makevalue’s commitment to:

  • Deliver robust, certified and enterprise-grade solutions

  • Enable seamless integration between core business platforms such as SAP and critical market infrastructures

  • Actively contribute to the evolution of the national and international technology ecosystem

Conclusion

The 5th SIBS Partners Meeting once again confirmed that the future is built on strong partnerships, continuous innovation and the responsible adoption of emerging technologies, particularly Artificial Intelligence. For the partners, this event was a moment of pride, exchange and strategic alignment, reinforcing our role as a trusted technology partner in complex integration and innovation projects

We remain fully committed to creating value, now strengthened by a recognition that reflects consistent work, close collaboration and a long-term vision.

entry.title: SAC Planning: Keep value unchanged when writing from higher to lower granularity
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I’m working with a planning-enabled model in SAP Analytics Cloud. On top of this model I built a Story with two tables. Both tables are based on the same model.

Setup

  • Table A contains the measure “Konditionswert (PLAN) Vorbelegung” (pre-fill / default value).

  • Table B contains the measure “Konditionswert (PLAN)” (plan value).

Both tables use the following dimensions in the rows:

  1. Account system owner (Kontosysteminhaber)

  2. Account system product (Kontosystemprodukt)

  3. Account system ID (Kontosystem-ID)

  4. Product (Produkt)

Table B additionally includes the dimension “Account (IBAN)”.
So Table A shows data on account-system-ID level, while Table B is more detailed on account (IBAN) level.

A single account system can have multiple accounts assigned to it, and each account belongs to exactly one account system.

What I’m trying to achieve

I want users to plan values in the “Pre-fill” measure. For example, they enter 12 in Table A.
I created a Data Action that copies values from “Pre-fill” into “Plan” when executed.

My goal is:
When a user enters a value in Pre-fill, the exact same value should be written into Plan (without changing it).

The problem

Because Table A is at account-system level and Table B is at account level, when I run the Data Action the value is automatically distributed evenly across the accounts.

Example:
If I enter 12 for account system ID 12345, which has 2 accounts, then SAC writes 6 into Plan for each account instead of writing 12.

What I need

I want to allow a pre-fill on account-system level that is then applied to the individual accounts, so users don’t have to plan each account manually.

What do I need to do so that when posting a number in Table A (account-system level), the number is written to Table B (account level) without being split, i.e. the value should be copied as-is?

Thanks a lot for any help!

Best regards,
Niklas

entry.title: Purchase Order per Account Assignment
entry.content:

I would like to have report for monitoring Purchase Orders which included the Cost Center or Project Task.

Could someone help me know if this is possible in this report? I have tried adding fields and could not find it.

Thank you in advance.

Jara

entry.title: Re: Embedded TM (S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025): Cro...
entry.content:
The documentation on SAP help and Oss notes described correct it's only support with FWO, In Freight Order, Internal Charge Calculation and Internal Settlement are not supported in S/4 HANA Embedded TM. It is only supported on the TM classic systems.(Side Car)

2985542 - S/4HANA TM: Internal Charges and Internal Settlement Document are not supported in FO Internal Settlement | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: Re: Customizing the Company Profitability Review Booklet in Margin Analysis
entry.content:
Hello @roman_rapp , thank you for the update, very interesting. 😀

Could you provide more information about the Filter: CurrencyField ?

This seems to be brand new because i have not seen anything like that. So far SAP provides an analytical app often in only one fix currency e.g. AmountInGlobalCurrency or AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency or AmountInTransactionCurrency and then all restricted measures are depend on it. Other apps provide measures in two or more CurrencyCodes but the number of measures is often limited to a small number to avoid confusion for the enduser, if all measures double or triple.

I tried to solve it by using an Extended view and join "CurrencyRole"

association [1..1] to C_LedgerCompanyCodeCrcyRoles as _CurrencyRole on $projection.ledger  = _CurrencyRole.Ledger
                                                                   and $projection.companycode  = _CurrencyRole.CompanyCode

 An in the analytical projection view

...
// On Demand Parameter to choose Company Code or Group Currency 
    @Consumption.defaultValue: '30'
    @EndUserText.label: 'Choose Currency (10/30), please'
    P_CurrencyRole                 : abap.numc( 2 ),
...
  //// Test for Gross sales from SD with CurrencyRole ////

  @EndUserText.label: 'Gross Sales Custom Price 30'
  @AnalyticsDetails.query.axis: #ROWS
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'GlobalCurrency'
  @Aggregation.default: #SUM
  case when SemanticTag = 'ZGS_C_PRIC'
  and GlobalCurrencyRole = $parameters.P_CurrencyRole          // 30 fix
  then curr_to_decfloat_amount ( AmountInGlobalCurrency )
  else null
  end                                                                                                            as GrossSalesCustomPriceGlobCurr,


  @EndUserText.label: 'Gross Sales Custom Price 10'
  @AnalyticsDetails.query.axis: #ROWS
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'CompanyCodeCurrency'
  @Aggregation.default: #SUM
  case when SemanticTag = 'ZGS_C_PRIC'
  and CompanyCodeCurrencyRole = $parameters.P_CurrencyRole     // 10 fix
  then curr_to_decfloat_amount ( AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency )
  else null
  end                                                                                                            as GrossSalesCustomPriceCCCurr,

  //// Test for Gross sales from SD with CurrencyRole ////

This worked somehow, but the result is that one of two measures is always "initial" and remained in the report as an "empty row". I then used Annotation @Analytics.settings.zeroValues but this also removes other "empty rows" that i don´t want to remove.

The issues lies in the fact, that "all measures are part of the measure structure" and "there can only be one measure structure". So my thoughts are: Why can´t there be two measure structure, one for "GroupCurrency" and one for "CompanyCodeCurreny" that can be choosen on the selection screen of a query?

While a second measure structure would fix the appearance in the query (only measures with CCC or GroupCry would show), what is not solved are the consequences in the CDS View. The CDS View would become significantly larger. See my code except. Same Semantic Tag but, same text ("Gross Sales Custom Price") but the issues lies within 

then curr_to_decfloat_amount ( AmountInGlobalCurrency )

then curr_to_decfloat_amount ( AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency )

 

So long story short. How does CurrencyField work in the given example?

Thank you, regards

David

entry.title: New ESAC (CQC) Pilot Deployment Readiness for SAP Signavio Process Manager and Collaboration Hub
entry.content:
Big news! Starting in Q1 2026, SAP Enterprise Support will launch a new pilot Continuous Quality Check (CQC) Deployment Readiness for SAP Signavio Process Manager and Collaboration Hub through the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council (ESAC).

 

This new CQC supports customers in reviewing configuration required to successfully deploy and adopt SAP Signavio Process Manager and SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub.

Watch this short introduction to the CQC Deployment Readiness for SAP Signavio Process Manager and Collaboration Hub
 

Scope

Organizations need trusted, efficient tools to model, share, and govern business processes across the enterprise.
This CQC helps customers confidently deploy SAP Signavio Process Manager and Collaboration Hub by ensuring all technical prerequisites, workspace configuration steps, and governance options are in place before the rollout.

Through this pilot engagement, you will receive guided support to:

  • Prepare your SAP Signavio workspace for modeling and collaboration
  • Validate required system connections and technical configurations
  • Ensure Collaboration Hub visibility, navigation, and governance settings align with organizational needs
  • Establish an environment where teams can quickly begin modeling, publishing, and reviewing processes in a shared workspace

This CQC is ideal for organizations seeking to accelerate SAP Signavio adoption and ensure a smooth, secure, and compliant deployment from day one.

As part of this CQC, SAP Enterprise Support experts will provide:

  • Technical validation of prerequisites required for SAP Signavio Process Manager and Collaboration Hub
  • Guidance and verification of workspace setup, including user access, attributes, modeling subsets, security settings, and folder structures
  • A final summary report outlining findings, configuration results, and recommendations

This ensures your teams begin with a solid technical foundation that supports consistent, compliant, and scalable process modeling and collaboration.
This CQC can be requested after customers complete the Expert Guided Implementations for SAP Signavio Process Manager and Collaboration Hub.

Prerequisites

To ensure a smooth onboarding process, customers should have:

  • Valid licenses for:
    • SAP Signavio Process Manager
    • SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub
  • A set‑up SAP Signavio workspace that includes Process Manager and Collaboration Hub
  • Appropriate user roles and access assigned for administrators and modelers
  • Any internal modeling conventions or audience‑specific requirements ready for deployment support

Outcome

After completing this CQC, you will have:

  • Clear validation on your SAP Signavio Collaboration Hub and Process Manager environment
  • Clear guidance on governance, modeling conventions, and administrative settings
  • A final report summarizing deployment readiness and recommended improvements
  • Confidence that your teams can begin modeling, sharing, and collaborating effectively and securely

Participation

  • This pilot is offered through the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council (ESAC).
  • To learn more about ESAC, visit the program website.

To register your interest, please contact us at: esac@sap.com
(Include your location or time zone and mention your interest in this pilot workstream.)

entry.title: Re: Customizing the Company Profitability Review Booklet in Margin Analysis
entry.content:
Hi David,

we have the Currency filter in all our booklets in Margin Analysis, so e.g. also in the Product Profitability and Project Financial booklets. This way you can display several currencies in parallel, also the Functional one, which would not work, if we had duplicated the full measure strcuture for each currency..

I am not the technical expert, but you can check the underlying CDS view C_COMPANYMARGINQUERY_2 and the underlying cube I_CompanyMarginCube_2 to see how it works technically. Both are C1 released, so you should be able to see them.

We have a dedicated view for the currency field:

define view entity I_CompanyMarginCurrencyField as select from I_CurrencyField {

@ObjectModel.text.association: '_Text'

key CurrencyField,

_Text

}

where CurrencyField = 'CCC'

or CurrencyField = 'GC'

or CurrencyField = 'FC'

 

which is used in the cube:

 

define view entity I_CompanyMarginCube_2

as select from I_GLAcctLineItemSemTagGLAcct as I_GLAcctLineItemSemTagGLAcct

 

association [0..1] to I_CompanyMarginCurrencyField as _CurrencyField on _CurrencyField.CurrencyField = $projection.CurrencyField

 

Then there is some cast logic in the cube, which you can copy to your needs.

 

I hope this helps.

 

Best regards,

Roman
